corpname.part: American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

did.abstract: Performance recordings, publicity, story drafts, photographs, and research files comprising the professional archive of storyteller Diane Wolkstein.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: Diane Wolkstein estate, Purchase, 2016; Rachel Zucker, Donation, 2024.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Diane Wolkstein collection was processed by Sara Ludewig and Ying-Ting "Serena" Chiu in 2023 and 2024.

AFC 2016/057: SR002 was deaccessioned by Sara Ludewig in January 2023, as the tape was discovered to be blank upon digitization. AFC 2016/057: SR147 and SR148 were deaccessioned in June 2024, as the tapes were discovered to be blank upon digitization.

In 2023, Sara Ludewig assigned each piece of digital media a unique digital ID number and Serena Chiu ripped audio discs from CDA to WAV format. Ludewig identified duplicate content or materials outside of the collection's scope and deaccessioned these digital carriers. She also deleted empty or temporary files and minimally arranged files within folders. Files retained their original file names and Ludewig processed each digital carrier into archival information packages (AIPs). Digital materials are described at the digital carrier level within their intellectual series. The optical discs that originally housed digital files were retained as part of the collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The rights to published materials created by Diane Wolkstein that are held by her beneficiary are governed by copyright for the lifetime of the beneficiary. When this term has expired, the rights to these materials enter the public domain. The rights to unpublished materials created by Diane Wolkstein are in the public domain. Rights belonging to third parties may be governed by copyright or other restrictions.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p:
The Diane Wolkstein collection is open to research. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at
https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Diane Wolkstein collection (AFC 2016/057), American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p:
Diane Wolkstein was a storyteller, author, and folklorist. Born in 1942, she received an undergraduate degree from Smith College, a master's degree in education from Bank Street College of New York, and studied mime under Etienne Decroux in Paris. She worked as New York City's official storyteller between 1967 and 1971 and later worked as a freelance storyteller. She performed stories for children every weekend in Central Park at the Hans Christian Andersen statue and hosted the radio show
Stories from Many Lands
on WNYC from 1968 to 1980. Wolkstein also traveled extensively to conduct fieldwork, gathering myths, stories, and songs to adapt and include in her storytelling. She was the author of two dozen books. Diane Wolkstein passed away in 2013 in Kaohsiung, Taiwan, while conducting research for a book of Chinese folk stories.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Papers and audiovisual materials comprising the professional archive of storyteller Diane Wolkstein. Includes performance events and productions, publicity materials, fieldwork interviews, publishing contracts, correspondence, field notes, and story drafts.

Wolkstein adapted folktales from many cultures for performance and publication, producing stories for both adults and children. The collection includes her recordings and notes from research in Haiti, China, Australia, and other locations, used to inform her stories. Also included in the collection are recordings of Wolkstein's radio program
Stories from Many Lands,
which ran from 1968 to 1980 on WNYC radio. In 2007, Wolkstein produced a documentary about her life and work entitled
A Storyteller's Story.
Materials used to produce the documentary are included as a part of the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Diane Wolkstein collection is organized in 8 series:

item.ref:
Series 4: WNYC
Stories From Many Lands
Radio Show (1967-1980)

Series 8:
A Storyteller's Story
documentary production files (1995-2007)

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

scopecontent.p: Field notes, correspondence, audio recordings, and photographs created by Diane Wolkstein when she conducted research to write stories. Fieldwork locations include Haiti, Egypt, China, Taiwan, India, and Greece.

scopecontent.p: Photographs, programs, scripts, and audio and video recordings of Wolkstein's storytelling performances at various venues. Includes materials from her work as a storyteller in Central Park.

arrangement.p: Arranged into groupings by file type, including performance photographs, programs, and scripts. Arranged chronologically within these groupings.

Series 4: WNYC
Stories From Many Lands

scopecontent.p:
Interview transcripts, programs, and audio recordings of
Stories from Many Lands,
produced and hosted by Diane Wolkstein, which aired on WNYC radio from 1968 to 1980.

arrangement.p: Arranged and described according to the numbering system used by Diane Wolkstein. This subseries is incomplete, not all of the episodes from Wolkstein's WNYC show are represented.

bibref.ref:
Andersen, Hans Christian.
Hans Christian Andersen Classic Stories.
Narrated by Diane Wolkstein and accompanied by Shirley Keller. Little Rock, AR: August House Audio, 2005. CD.

Andersen, Hans Christian.
Hans Christian Andersen in Central Park.
Narrated by Diane Wolkstein. Weston, CT: Weston Woods, 1981. CD.

Courlander, Harold.
Tales of the Hopi Indians.
Narrated by Diane Wolkstein. 1975. Sound cassette.

Psyche and Eros.
Translated and narrated by Diane Wolkstein. Montvale, NJ: Cloudstone Productions, 1984. Sound cassette.

Shannon, Monica.
The Artistic Pig.
Narrated by Diane Wolkstein. 1974. Sound cassette.

Shannon, Monica.
The Bean Boy.
Narrated by Diane Wolkstein. 1974. Sound cassette.

Shannon, Monica.
Diane Wolkstein Tells California Fairy Tales.
Narrated by Diane Wolkstein. 1985. Sound cassette.

Shannon, Monica.
An Enchanted Gypsy.
Narrated by Diane Wolkstein. 1974. Sound cassette.

Shannon, Monica.
The First Hat.
Narrated by Diane Wolkstein. 1974. Sound cassette.

Wolkstein, Diane.
The Banza: A Haitian Story.
Illustrated by Marc Brown. New York: Dial Books for Young Readers, 1981.

Wolkstein, Diane.
Bouki Dances the Kokioko: A Comical Tale from Haiti.
Illustrated by Jesse Sweetwater. San Diego, CA: Harcourt Brace, 2001.

Wolkstein, Diane.
The Cool Ride in the Sky.
Illustrated by Paul Galdone. New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 1973.

Wolkstein, Diane.
The Day the Ocean Came to Visit.
Illustrated by Steve Johnson and Lou Fancher. San Diego, CA: Harcourt, 2001.

Wolkstein, Diane.
Dream Songs: Abulafia, Part of My Heart.
New York: Cloudstone, 1991.

Wolkstein, Diane.
The Epic of Inanna.
Narrated by Diane Wolkstein. Music by Geoffrey Gordon. Montvale, NJ: Cloudstone, 1986. Sound cassette.

Wolkstein, Diane.
Eskimo Stories.
Narrated by Diane Wolkstein. Music by Avraham Qanai and L.S. Messina. New Rochelle, NY: Spoken Arts, 1985. Sound cassette.

Wolkstein, Diane.
Esther's Story.
Illustrated by Juan Wijingaard. New York: Morrow Junior Books, 1996.

Wolkstein, Diane.
Estonian Fairy Tales.
Narrated by Diane Wolkstein. Translated by Selve Maas. Music by Lilian Esop. D. Wolkstein, 1988. Sound cassette.

Wolkstein, Diane.
The First Love Stories: From Isis and Osiris to Tristan and Iseult.
New York: Harper Collins, 1991.

Wolkstein, Diane.
The Glass Mountain.
Illustrated by Louisa Bauer. New York: Morrow Junior Books, 1999.

Wolkstein, Diane.
Lazy Stories.
Illustrated by James Marshall. New York: The Seabury Press, 1976.

Wolkstein, Diane.
The Legend of Sleepy Hollow: Based on the Story by Washington Irving.
Illustrated by R.W. Alley. New York: William Morrow and Company, 1987.

Wolkstein, Diane.
Little Mouse's Painting.
Illustrated by Maryjane Begin. New York: Morrow Junior Books, 1992.

Wolkstein, Diane.
The Magic Orange Tree, and Other Haitian Folktales.
Illustrated by Elsa Henriquez. New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 1978.

Wolkstein, Diane.
The Magic Wings: A Tale from China.
Illustrated by Robert Andrew Parker. New York: Dutton, 1983.

Wolkstein, Diane.
Oom Razoom, or Go I Know Not Where, Bring Back I Know Not What: A Russian Tale.
Illustrated by Dennis McDermott. New York: Morrow Junior Books, 1991.

Wolkstein, Diane.
Owl: A Folktale from Haiti in the Caribbean.
Illustrated by Tracey Fennell. London, UK: BBC Educational Publishing, 1991.

Wolkstein, Diane.
The Red Lion: A Tale of Ancient Persia.
Illustrated by Ed Young. New York: Crowell, 1977.

Wolkstein, Diane.
Romping.
Narrated by Diane Wolkstein. Music by Shirley Keller. Montvale, NJ: Cloudstone Productions, 1985. Sound cassette.

Wolkstein, Diane.
Squirrel's Song: A Hopi Indian Tale.
Illustrated by Lillian Hoban. New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 1976.

Wolkstein, Diane.
Step by Step.
Illustrated by Joseph A. Smith. New York: Morrow Junior Books, 1994.

Wolkstein, Diane.
The Story of Joseph: Its Scriptures and Midrash.
Narrated by Diane Wolkstein. Montvale, NJ: Cloudstone, 1986.

Wolkstein, Diane.
Sun Mother Wakes the World: An Australian Creation Story.
Illustrated by Bronwyn Bancroft. New York: Harper Collins, 2004.

Wolkstein, Diane.
Treasures of the Heart: Holiday Stories that Reveal the Soul of Judaism.
New York: Schocken Books, 2003.

Wolkstein, Diane.
The Visit.
Illustrated by Lois Ehlert. New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 1977.

Wolkstein, Diane.
White Wave: A Chinese Tale.
Illustrated by Ed Young. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell Company, 1979.

Wolkstein, Diane and Samuel Noah Kramer.
Inanna, Queen of Heaven and Earth: Her Stories and Hymns from Sumer.
Art compiled by Elizabeth Williams-Forte. New York: Harper and Row, 1983.
